title: Riot said it themselves, Rek'Sai's subtitle could be cooler

embed.description: A burrow of Rek'Sai. What possessed me to follow Uncle's Noxian trappers there? And on the threshold of this beast's realm, with the evidence right before us, why didn't we turn back? It was as if we were standing on the edge of a great cliff and were seized by some primal instinct to lean against that emptiness until we plummeted to our deaths.

body:
Now, I think we all know that Rek'Sai's sub-title could have been MUCH better. The Void Burrower just doesn't really suit her. And then Riot releases this page on the website.

>Rek'Sai: Scourge of the Desert

Riot, why couldn't you have used that as her sub-title!? That's so awesome and fits her perfectly!
Upvote and bump for justice!

{{champion:421}} *Approved by Rek'Sai, Scourge of the Desert*

replies.body: I thought Gragas was Scourge of the Dessert. {{champion:79}}
Naaaah! Gragas is well known for rousing some serious rabble.

"subtitle"

https://backtothethames.files.wordpress.com/2014/10/inigomontoya.jpg

That quibble aside, I agree. "The Void Burrower" sounds pretty dull. That might work if this were a literal subtitle, or perhaps spoken narration for visually impaired viewers ("a Void Burrower attacks"), but it's a very literal way to refer to the Champion, and strikes me as strange-sounding.

I'm reminded of Orianna being changed from "The Clockwork Girl" to "The Lady of Clockwork" due to some alleged IP concern. (I think?) I thought that was a weak change. (As one friend observed to me, even "The Lady Clockwork" would have a better sound to it.)

I recall reading that there are two main schools of thought in Riot about Champion titles: some think they should be sort of poetic and abstract, while others thing they should be very literal. The example given was Skarner, as "the Crystal Vanguard"; one Rioter said that if it had been up to them, he'd be called "the Crystal Scorpion".

Personally, I prefer the more descriptive titles, as I think you do as well. For instance, I think it's cooler to have Garen known as "the Might of Demacia" than "the Demacian Warrior" or "the Armored Knight" or something.

Subtitle: a subordinate title of a published work or article giving additional information about its content.

In this case, the article is the champion and the subtitle is "Scourge of the Desert."

> [{quoted}](name=Glescoron,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=R0QAbvqb,comment-id=00030001,timestamp=2014-12-13T07:45:32.945+0000)
> Subtitle: a subordinate title of a published work or article giving additional information about its content.
> 
> In this case, the article is the champion and the subtitle is "Scourge of the Desert."

What word we use to refer to the phrase that describes a giant sand monster from the Void is perhaps not the most important topic around. Still, for what it's worth, I think "title" sounds more natural than "subtitle", given the frequent use of the latter to refer to movie subtitles.

For example, consider "King George, Defender of the Faith". You could say that "King" or "King George" is his title, and call "Defender of the Faith" his subtitle, but I believe it's much more common to call "Defender of the Faith" a title.

It'd be much more accurate if you said 'epithet' instead of "subtitle". Since "subtitle" is meant for written works and epithet is meant for a person or thing. Sorry for getting off-topic but this sort of thing bothers me in the same way calling a human being an "it" does.

> [{quoted}](name=Myquillian,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=R0QAbvqb,comment-id=0003000100000001,timestamp=2014-12-14T07:53:57.650+0000)
> It'd be much more accurate if you said 'epithet' instead of "subtitle". Since "subtitle" is meant for written works and epithet is meant for a person or thing. Sorry for getting off-topic but this sort of thing bothers me in the same way calling a human being an "it" does.

I kind of prefer "title" to "epithet", if only because of the stock phrase "racial epithet". Words that are technically precise may perform poorly in the wild due to their common connotations and associations.

Like that time freshman year when I noticed a girl's hands were very cold, sought for a word meaning "very cold", and naively informed her, "You're frigid!" My insistence that I was simply referring to her temperature, strangely enough, didn't quite save the day.
Very understandable... and relatable.

Fair enough, I can see where you're coming from. I'd say it's important to read into the context around a word, so subtitle and title may as well be interchangeable. We're all on the same page anyways.
